problemStatement.formal: \forall k \geq 1, \forall^\infty n, n = \sum c_i a_i \text{ with } a_i \in P(d_i, k)
problemStatement.plain: Prove the strong version of Erdős #124: with gcd condition, representations can exclude low-order digits (P(dᵢ, k) for arbitrary k ≥ 1).
whyMatters: Generalizes the solved Question 1 to higher digit positions
The {3,4,7} case is already proven - can we extend to other base tuples?
Connects to additive number theory and digit representations

proven: Q1 fully proved (Aristotle/Alexeev): Σ 1/(dᵢ-1) ≥ 1 suffices for P(dᵢ, 0)
Full Lean formalization in Erdos124Problem.lean (97 lines) and Erdos124CompleteSequences.lean (507 lines)
open: Q2 for general base tuples beyond {3,4,7}
Understanding which base tuples with gcd = 1 satisfy Q2
knownResults.goal: Extend Q2 proof to more base tuples or prove in general

currentState.focus: Initial survey of existing formalization and open directions
currentState.nextAction: Study Erdos124CompleteSequences.lean to understand proof technique for {3,4,7}

knowledge.progressSummary: SURVEY: Existing formalization is substantial (604 lines total). Q1 fully axiomatized, Q2 partially proved for {3,4,7}. The 'strong' version is Q2.
insights: The 'strong' version excluding d^0=1 is precisely Question 2 from the Erdős problem
P(d, k) means digits starting from position k, so P(d, 0) allows d^0=1 terms
The gcd condition gcd(d₁,...,dᵣ) = 1 is needed for Q2
Existing proof for {3,4,7}: 1/2 + 1/3 + 1/6 = 1 satisfies reciprocal condition, gcd(3,4,7) = 1
Key technique likely involves showing digit representations become dense enough at higher positions
mathlibGaps: No general theory of digit-restricted representations in Mathlib

Identify if proof generalizes to other tuples like {3,4,5}
Verify {3,4,5} satisfies reciprocal and gcd conditions
Attempt Q2 for {3,4,5} if techniques transfer
